comments:
The course introduces students to topics in energy, with its foundations in technology, association to economics, and impacts on ecology and society. The course spans from basic principles to applications. A review of energy consumption, use, and resources; ecological impacts, sustainability and design of sustainable energy systems; methods of energy analysis; forecasting; electricity generation systems (steam and gas turbine based power plants, fuel cells), energy for transportation (cars, aircraft, and ships); nuclear energy and wastes; renewable energy use: solar, wind, hydroelectric, geothermal, biomass; prospects for future energy systems: fusion power, power generation in space.

Students generally found the course’s guest lectures to be enjoyable and informative. However, a number of students were disappointed with the course given the great potential of the subject matter. Several found the materials to be interesting, but thought that readings were irrelevant and excessive.  Many felt that they were unable to go in-depth into topics due to the pacing of the course.

Overall, students found Professor Lior to be an expert at the subject matter, but many felt that his lectures and slides were poorly structured and disorganized. Several students also commented that Professor Lior was “not engaging” and unable to stimulate interest in class.

This course is part of the Sustainability and Environmental Management minor. Many students commented that it was difficult for those who did not have an engineering background.
